title: Acute Radiation Syndrome
summary: Acute radiation syndrome (ARS) occurs following high-dose whole-body or significant partial-body irradiation, characterized by prodromal, latent, manifest illness, and recovery phases with distinct clinical presentations.

content.text: ARS results from radiation damage to rapidly dividing cell populations, particularly hematopoietic, gastrointestinal, and neurovascular systems. The severity depends on dose, dose rate, and extent of body exposure.

Prodromal phase (0-48 hours): nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, fatigue. Latent phase (48 hours-weeks): apparent recovery. Manifest illness phase: bone marrow, GI, or neurovascular syndrome. Recovery phase: gradual improvement or death.

Hematopoietic syndrome (1-10 Gy): lymphopenia, thrombocytopenia, anemia. GI syndrome (10-50 Gy): severe diarrhea, dehydration, infection. Neurovascular syndrome (>50 Gy): altered consciousness, seizures, death within days.
Lymphocyte count depression within 48 hours is the most reliable early indicator of significant radiation exposure and dose estimation.
